comment.author: 22716314@N06
comment._content: I think this may be a wife from the Loew Theater family.

comment.author: 23164421@N06
comment._content: According to an article in Time Magazine (January 7, 1935), "Mrs. Florence ('Queenie') Loew was the daughter of the late great George Fisher Baker." See: www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748315,00.html

comment.author: 27398485@N08
comment._content: Possibly Mrs William Goadby Loew, or E. Victor Loew - society leaders of New York?  Their wives are mentioned in New York Times articles of that era as hostess of balls, events - with the likes of Mrs Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs Alfred G. Vanderbilt, Mrs Stuyvesent Fish all part of the Newport Circle. She would have attended balls and dinners at Crossways, the Breakers, Beaulieu all famous mansions of New York Society of the Gilded Age.

comment.author: 96684819@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called 1910s Fashion, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The name "Mrs. W. G. Loew" is actually inscribed on the negative. The Bain collection has other photos of her in which she is identified in full as Mrs. William Goadby Loew.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
Wystan: 

Thank you for the more complete name for Mrs. Loew. We will add the more full name when we update the record.

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called brilliant magic, and we'd love to have this added to the group! for international woman week

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I did some research and found she is Florence Bellows Baker Loew. I started an entry in Wikipedia for her: Florence Bellows Baker Loew (1876–1936) was a horse woman and philanthropist and award winning horticulturist. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Bellows_Baker

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks Richard Arthur Norton for finding her full name.  We will add it to the information when we update the database.
